column2: Ajahn Pasanno reads and discusses a series of suttas regarding the human condition.

column6: Session title

column6: The Human Situation

column3: 2016-06-25 Sutta Study Upasika Day Responding to the Human Situation.mp3
column6: Responding to the Human Situation
Text
"[Befriending the Suttas](https://www.accesstoinsight.org/befriending.html)" at [accesstoinsight.org](https://accesstoinsight.org).
You mentioned suttas about meditation and practical life issues. Are there any other general categories of suttas?
How do these particular teachings (AN 5.48: Situations) fit with kamma?
I appreciate that AN 5.48 includes devas and Māra.
In the West, we personalize every bit of suffering. Is it different in Thailand?
Ajahn Pasanno can't translate guilt into Thai.
That's really suffering. Tell them not to do that.|Ajahn Paññānanda
_Can't We Talk about Something More Pleasant?_ by Roz Chast (commercial).
In this sutta (AN 5.48), there's the assumption that everyone has enemies. It's making me a little paranoid.
With development (bhavana), is one able to shape the course of sickness or heal oneself to a degree?
I've been reflecting on how AN 5.48 applies to environmental and collective well-being–engaging without the expectation that actions will have a certain result.
I find it difficult to find the line between what you can change and what you can't.
Michael Olds translates sutta as 'magical spell.' The format, repetition, and structure of the suttas has a certain potency. When I read the suttas after meditating, it's completely different.
AN 7.6: Treasures.
A man in an airport asks Ajahn Chah, "If everyone is Buddhist, why are there so many thieves in Thailand?"
When I practice and share Dhamma as a lay person, others complain when I make mistakes.
Once a junior monk approached Ajahn Chah and listed all Ajahn Chah's faults. Ajahn Chah replied, "It's a good thing you're not looking for perfection in yourself!"
When I hear the word "shame," it's.a cousin of guilt. But in this context (AN 7.6), it seems more acceptable.
This year my whole family got lice. How do we respond to this skillfully?
Ajahn Pasanno visits the elderly Cambodian monk Mahāgossānanda who has Alzheimer's disease.
That thing you learn in meditation—that you don't lose.|Ajahn Fuang
A monk known for psychic powers visits Ajahn Chah's sick room and reports: "You don't have to worry about Ajahn Chah. His heart is so bright."
A diligent early support of Wat Pah Nanachat reflects, "I don't have money, but I'm not poor."
Is the list of Seven Treasures sequential?

I like the translations 'conscience' and 'concern' for hiri and otappa. Having done unskillful actions in the past that create suffering, and being aware of the tendency to personalize, how can it be over and done?
As a human being, I have the opportunity to learn from the past and move on to skillful action in the future. I don't have to be like a dog that barfs stuff up and goes back and eats it again.

The not-self refrain, 'This is not me, this is not mine, this is not what or who I am,' is not an abdication of responsibility but an understanding, 'This is the way I can put things down and move on, move past the things that are still creating suffering.'
SN 42.8 The Conch Blower; AN 3.100: A Lump of Salt.
What is a good balance between listening to Dhamma and practicing more deeply? How long should one keep one's practices, and when to expand or shrink them?
I listen to the Abhayagiri Dhamma talks, focusing more on the timbre of the voice rather than trying to get an intellectual grasp of what was said. That projects me into a dimension of well-being.
about ongoing Dhamma practice and coming back to the heart.
We're making choices all the time anyway; we may as well choose to be happy.
When you're living on the precepts, how do I relate to (for example) a friend who tells me about an affair they are having?
Don't admonish your fellow monks before the meal.|Ajahn Chah
Could you comment on the tendency to use one aspect of the teaching to bypass another?
With some things, letting go means you're willing to commit to hard work, and other times you're willing to put down what is burdensome.
AN 5.38 says, 'Not by sorrow can even the slightest good come.' How does this work with the natural process of grieving?
Part of the sense of loss and sorrow is the joys that have created attachment. How to approach this?
Thag 1062: Mahākassapa delights in nature.
